title: Speed Limit Should be 40 & Dangerous/Negligent Driving
comment: Households in Milford Drive area (Sovereign Hills Estate) need to be educated about driving safely to road conditions. Overtaking cars that have reversed out of driveways, including overtaking up on footpaths, cutting corners when no view of oncoming traffic or parked cars, tailgating and abusing drivers who are driving with more care and concern for residents and other road users. A more appropriate speed limit would be 40. Signs needed at bottom of hill approaching blind corners such as " slow down - cars reversing", "Keep Left" sign on the corners near Mindaribba - most cars cutting these corners are driving too fast for the road conditions. Multiple accidents and near misses. Alternatively a low concrete barrier in middle to force cars to stay on their side but busses can manoeuvre over/ around. Possible a flyer/notice to all households about safe driving / more respect for fellow residents and road users. Council could request police to make regular patrols of area. Of particular concern is the general stereotype that such unsafe and disrespectful road use is mostly from P Plate drivers. Sadly, in this area the majority of drivers displaying blatant unsafe behaviours are adults, very often with child passengers who will grow up thinking it is OK to drive in such a manner in a busy residential area.

title: Aggressive bumps, concrete obstacles and bike lines
comment: Redfern rd Minto is a wide and safe street with footpaths down both sides. Why then is the actually driving area of the road so restricted and cluttered with obstacles? There are two separate bike paths running down the road to the station - the footpath is marked and signposted as a dedicated cycle lane so the addition of further unused cycle room on the actual road is unnecessary. The roundabouts which are supposed to maintain the flow of traffic are dangerous due to the amount of concrete and obstacles surrounding them. I have seen a couple of near misses there as the attention of drivers is focused on navigating their vehicle through the tight space into the roundabout and not on the roundabout itself, nor on the other traffic in or approaching the roundabout. The Kent st roundabout is particularly bad and I would suggest also not required for this quiet T intersection. The addition of a very aggressive bump in this already restricted and difficult to navigate piece of road takes further attention away from the traffic at the roundabout. This aggressive bump is a 'first gear' bump and further bottle-necks traffic flowing down the road. Traffic can now be backed up from the bump to the school and even the traffic lights, as each driver shifts down to first gear to get through this roundabout. Again, roundabouts are designed to maintain traffic flow. This roundabout is unnecessary and the obstacles around it are distracting and dangerous. The additional aggressive bump at the station is also unnecessary and a further distraction reducing the flow of traffic. The bump is right on the entry to a right angle bend at the station. Cars are already slowing down to second gear to go around the bend and the addition of a first gear bump into the bend is unnecessary, a distraction and dangerous. There is a lot of foot traffic at the station and further distractions in the form of this bump and the concrete bumper lanes are unsafe. One might also ask why the existing concrete median was torn up only to be re-laid the same week?

I was carrying a bottle in my right hand, it smashed as I landed and I sustained two deep cuts to my left hand which wax extended to protect my fall. That night I had to locate and attend an emergency department at Concord Hospital, the arm was treated superficially and immobilised in a cast as there was glass deeply embedded in a cut; then return to the hospital for the whole of the next day prepped and awaiting a general anaesthetic and plastic surgery to clean the wounds thoroughly and remove a large piece of glass. This affected my holiday; along with shock and discomfort, it meant that I had to change flights, as I was booked to fly to Hobart on Monday but medically unready to fly. I will follow up with the Canada Bay Council as I am unhappy about what happened for myself through no fault of my own, and what could happen for other pedestrians, such as a father I saw walking up the street briskly with his toddler on his shoulders, or frail elders. I have a number of photos of the footpath.

title: Open this fire trail, as an extension of Bundanoon Rd Woronora Heights
comment: This easement was closed in 2006 by rezoning it to 7A environment protected by order of Frank Sartor, Planning Minister. This was contrary to the advice of his planning team. It was hoped to get the road opened as originally determined in the Land an Environment Court in 1982, however strong opposition mainly from people in the Valley supported by the then Labor state MP Alison Magerrity persuade Frank Sartor to act on his own. Closure of this road causes the 3000+ residents of Woronora Heights to travel over 2000 kms annually to get in and out of their suburb. Moreover it has stopped the bus company to provide the residents of Woronora Heights and Valley a decent peak period bus service direct to Sutherland station which would reduce daily travel times for many by up to 40 minutes. Consequently many of these residents travel to work by car or drive to and park close by Sutherland station adding to the unnecessary and considerable parking congestion there. There have been many reports prepared over the past 25 years on this issue and in favour of opening this road and they should now be re-considered. There are dis-benefits to some peoples' life style as with all road projects but the overwhelming benefits to the overall community should be taken into consideration rather than to pandering the vocal minority to get more votes at elections State or Shire.

title: Dangerous traffic calming circle at intersection
comment: I find this part of the road to be quite dangerous and have hit the traffic calming circle during night driving, after turning right from Wollongong Road to proceed to the traffic lights at Wolli Creek rd and Forest Rd. It's caused by a dip in the t-section break on the eastern side of the intersection on Wolli Creek Rd, in the direction for cars travelling west and east-bound, combined with a broken lane divider barrier at the junction of the intersection in this area to direct traffic between the lanes operating east. Cars trying to turn right coming from a southerly direction on Wollongong Rd gave the stop sign and a pedestrian crossing to deal with just before the intersection. I have found on many occasions that quite a few cars that are travelling west on Wolli Creek Rd, after coming through the lights, slow down thinking they need to give way to the drivers waiting to right turn into Wolli Creek rd from Wollongong Rd, travelling north. Consequently, traffic banked up travelling east to the left of this intersection then rushes through to catch the lights, and anyone who misjudges the central traffic calmer can run straight over/into it, while trying to change lanes anticipating the right hand lane turn light remaining green. I suggest that a chicane-style traffic calmer barrier be placed here for cars travelling west on Wolli creek Rd, or alternatively a small roundabout to regulate smoother flow of traffic. Consequent slower light changes for the traffic signals going straight through in an east direction (this is currently the left lane of the road only) at the intersection of Wolli Creek rd and Forest Rd would regulate traffic bank-up in this section better than drivers can manage manually with the current arrangements now. I am happy to discuss this idea with road engineers and town planners at Rockdale Council if required. title: Footpath hazard -pedestrian safety

The problem is worsened by the fact that on this very same corner is a bus stop where the school bus stops every day, hence children do not have the choice to walk on the other side of the road. Additionally, across the road on waratah road is a children's day care centre which creates additional foot traffic all around this very same corner. It would also appear that during heavy rain, excess rainwater run-off from the council street floods into this grassy area without adequate drainage mitigation via appropriate kerbing and guttering. The installation of kerbing and guttering is a minimum to help remediate what poses an otherwise unacceptable safety risk to young children and residents who have no choice but to be using this particular section of the road. A proper footpath would be idea but as a safety measure, kerbing is required. The same corner has been responsible for several cars losing control and hitting walls and trees. Kerbing would be an inexpensive way to divert rainwater to drains, avoid mud pits and channel cars to correctly navigate the corner without spinning out onto the grass verge. Before someone gets killed or injured, I urge council to address this issue.
